Chapter on Hungry Ghosts, Part Two
Next, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they contemplate the hungry ghost KÄma (KÄma, two lupo in Wei, means desire and form). Due to what karma are they born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:

If a person, whether male, female, or eunuch, wears various clothes to adorn themselves, wears women's clothes, and practices as a prostitute, if someone desires them, they have sexual relations with them, and obtain wealth from this, and give it to ordinary people;
to a non-field of blessings, they give with an impure mind.
For this reason, when their body perishes and their life ends, they are born among the hungry ghosts of desire and form.

After receiving a ghost body, they are adorned in various ways, and whatever they think of is accomplished according to their wishes. If they desire good, it is beautiful; if they desire evil, it is ugly.
If they wish to create desirable or undesirable forms, they can do so all.
They can transform into a man with a handsome face;
or a woman with a beautiful figure;
or an animal with a unique appearance.
They can create various wonderful adornments and travel everywhere.
If they obtain food and drink, they can eat without harm, because they have practiced giving a little.
They can use their tiny bodies to sneak into people's homes to seek food and drink. The people of the world say:
The ghost of a piÅ›Äca has stolen my food and drink.
They may take on a human form to enter others' festivals;
or take on the form of a bird to eat people's sacrificial food.
Their bodies are subtle and people cannot see them.
This ghost can manifest various forms as they wish. People all call them gandharva spirits.
They may take on the form of a woman to have intercourse with a man. In this way, they deceive people with various adornments and roam among humans.
In the realm of ghosts, until their evil karma is exhausted, destroyed, and decayed, they cannot escape;
when the karma is exhausted, they can escape.

After death, they transmigrate according to their karma, experiencing the suffering of birth and death. Obtaining a human body is difficult, like a turtle in the ocean encountering the hole in a floating log.

If reborn as a human, they fall into the ranks of entertainers, wearing various clothes and indulging in play to seek a living, using their own wives to engage in activities with others to seek wealth.
Due to remaining karma, they receive such retribution.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they observe the hungry ghosts on the ocean isles. Due to what karma are they born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:
In a past life, these beings saw travelers wishing to cross the wilderness, suffering from illness and exhaustion. They took much payment from these people but provided little in return.
Because of this evil greed, they deceive those traveling in the wilderness with skillful words.
For this reason, they are born on an island in the ocean.

On this island in the ocean, there are no trees, ponds, or rivers. The place is extremely hot. In the winter, it is extremely hot, surpassing ten times the heat of summer in the human realm. They can only sustain themselves on morning dew.
Although they live on an island in the ocean, they cannot obtain water. Due to their evil karma, they see the ocean dry up;
Even if they see trees, they are all ablaze with great flames. Their hopes are cut off, and all kinds of evil gather without any peace.

Hunger and thirst burn their bodies, causing them to moan and lament in grief and distress. Deceived by their own minds, they run around everywhere, crying out in despair, without any savior, protector, support, or reliance;

Their hair is disheveled and their bodies are emaciated, with all the veins in their bodies clearly visible like a net. Wherever they go, everything is exhausted, with no savior, no refuge, no support.
Because their evil karma has not yet been exhausted, destroyed, or decayed, they are not allowed to die;
only when their karma is exhausted can they escape.

After they die, they continue to transmigrate according to their karma, experiencing the suffering of birth and death. Obtaining a human body is as difficult as a sea turtle encountering the hole in a floating log.
If they are born among humans, they are born on an island in the ocean, either with only one foot or with short feet, suffering from lack of water.
Because of their remaining karma, they receive such retribution.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they observe the hungry ghosts of Yama's realm who wield staffs. Due to what karma are they born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:

These sentient beings, due to stinginess and jealousy, destroy their own minds. They associate with kings, ministers, and the powerful, and exclusively engage in violence and evil, with no compassion or kindness. They do not follow proper principles and are despised by the virtuous.
Such evil people, when their bodies perish and their lives end, receive the body of a staff-wielding ghost under the control of King Yama. In the ghost realm, they run errands for King Yama.
If there are sentient beings who commit evil deeds, King Yama will then order these ghosts to record their spirits.

The color of these ghosts' bodies is ugly and terrifying. They hold knives and staffs in their hands, with disheveled hair covering their bodies. Their lips hang down, their ears are long, and they have large stomachs. They shout loudly to frighten the ghosts. They hold sharp knives, pointing at the criminals, and grab their hands with ropes to bind them. They lead them to the king and say to the great king:
I have captured this criminal from among humans and brought him here. Great king!
This person, in their past lives, engaged in unwholesome actions, with unwholesome physical, verbal, and mental actions, and wishes for the king to reprimand them.
At that time, King Yama will speak a verse of admonition, saying:
You are the foolish ones among humans, adorning yourselves with various evil actions.
Why did you not cultivate wholesome conduct?
It is like going to a treasure island and returning empty-handed.
The causes and conditions of wholesome actions lead to the fruit of happiness, and the causes and conditions of the fruit of happiness give rise to a wholesome mind.
All dharmas follow the mind and revolve in birth and death, constantly without interruption.
All conditioned things are impermanent, like water bubbles, not solid.
If one is able to cultivate the true Dharma in this way, this person will obtain a superior reward in the future.
If there are people who are always able to cultivate goodness and abandon all evil actions,
this person will not come to me, but will ascend the steps and be reborn to receive the heavenly reward.
If a person is foolish and lacks understanding, delights in evil karma and comes to me,
If one can abandon evil karma and unwholesome deeds, this person then practices the foremost path.
If one sees the fruits of actions in the world, and also sees the various pleasures in the heavens,
If one still gives rise to a mind of heedlessness, this person is not said to love his own body.
For whose benefit does one create evil karma, indulging the body, speech, and mind in everything?
Such people have different practices, and now your karmic retribution has come to me.
You are deceived by many evils, and will definitely proceed along a perilous and evil path,
If a person delights in creating evil karma, it will be very difficult to obtain a human body in the future.
If a person stays far away from evil karma, and delights in practicing good dharmas with a loving mind,
This person will always be at ease in this life, and will certainly attain the fruit of liberation and nirvana.
If there are sentient beings who cultivate wholesome conduct, they are the most distinguished in the world;
If a person cultivates unwholesome actions, it is the greatest evil in all worlds.
If there are wise people who practice wholesome conduct, they can avoid unwholesome dharmas from beginning to end;
If there are those who create and cultivate many unwholesome actions, they will enter hell and receive the retribution of suffering.
If one can use wholesome dharmas to subdue the faculties, one will attain the pure and supreme dharmas of the world,
And when this person's body perishes and life ends, they will be reborn in the heavenly palace and receive blissful rewards.
Karma binds you very tightly, and you are held by the messengers of Yama;
You are sent to the terrifying evil paths, the great place of suffering in Yama's realm.
The many evils you have created in your past lives, this karma you will now receive yourself;
What you yourself create, you yourself receive, not for others. If others create it, it is not your own retribution.

Thus, after Yama reproaches the sinners, the messengers lead them out. These sinners, having created evil karma themselves and deceived by their own karma, will experience various sufferings as retribution.
They are tortured, tormented by hunger and thirst, and only eat wind and air. Because their evil karma has not been exhausted, they are not allowed to die;
After escaping from this, they continue to transmigrate and experience the suffering of birth and death according to their karma.

If they are born among humans, they will be born in border areas, in secluded mountains, dangerous valleys, deep rivers, steep cliffs, and perilous places, and will be made to guide those who have power and travel these roads.
Due to their remaining karma, they will experience this karmic retribution.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally on the Dharma. How does a bhiká¹£u contemplate the five stages?
With his wisdom of hearing, he clearly observes the ten kinds of color-entry.
What are the ten?
First, the eye-entry;
second, the form-entry;ğŸ”½third, the ear-entry;
fourth, the sound-entry;
Fifth, the nose sense-field;
Sixth, the smell sense-field;
Seventh, the tongue sense-field;
Eighth, the taste sense-field;
Ninth, the body sense-field;
Tenth, the touch sense-field.
How does a bhiká¹£u observe the eye and forms?

A bhiká¹£u observes that the eye and forms give rise to consciousness, and the combination of these three factors gives rise to contact. Contact is accompanied by feeling, perception, volition, and cognition.

The characteristics of contact are touched, the characteristics of feeling are experienced, the characteristics of perception are cognition, such as long and short, liked and disliked, directly perceived and corresponding, etc. Volition is the cognition of a single condition, and each has its own characteristics. There are three parts, either form or non-form, each with its own substance, like the ten universal mental factors.
What are the ten?
First, feeling;
Second, perception;
Third, volition;
Fourth, contact;
Fifth, attention;
Sixth, desire;
Seventh, release;
Eighth, mindfulness;
Ninth, concentration;
Tenth, wisdom.

Each of them has its own characteristics, such as being a single condition and yet being mutually distinct. One dharma is also like this. It is just like sunlight, which arises together with the various lights, each with its own distinct nature.
Just as the nature of consciousness is distinct, so is thought.
That bhiká¹£u thus knows the eye sense-field as it really is, observes that the eye is empty, without anything, without solidity, and without reality.

The bhiká¹£u thus knows the path as it really is, abandons wrong views, and with right view his mind is joyful. The eye is free from the defilement of delusion. He truly sees that the eye is merely a piece of flesh, and that delusion is ignorant and merely a tear duct.
Having truly known this, he abandons lustful thoughts and observes that the eye is impermanent.

Having known it to be impermanent, it is merely a mass of flesh residing in a cavity. Truly knowing the eye, he knows that it is bound by sinews and blood vessels, and that the eye sense-field exists through the combination of various conditions.
Such an eye has no seer, no self, and no cognition. Even suffering is like this.
Having observed the eye sense-field, he attains a mind free from desire.
This bhiká¹£u, having contemplated the eye-faculty as it truly is, discriminates and observes forms:
Such forms, whether loved or unloved, are all indeterminate, arising from discrimination.
What is there to be seen?
What is pure?
What is permanent?
What is there to crave?
The bhiká¹£u thus contemplates and observes, truly knowing that forms do not exist, are not happiness.
Thus he contemplates and observes:
Are not the characteristics of forms without solidity, without reality, arising from discrimination, loved or unloved, not truly existent?

All sentient beings, in vain attachment to the loved and unloved, such forms do not have a self-nature, are not permanent, do not exist, are not true, are not happiness, are not indestructible, are not solid, are not the self. It is because of greed, anger, and delusion that one's mind is covered and one gives rise to the loved and unloved. Is it not that forms have love and have no love?
Because of the arising of recollection.
The bhiká¹£u observes the sense-field of form in this way. Having seen name-and-form, he is not greedy, not attached, not deluded, and does not grasp. He knows that form is not solid.
That bhiká¹£u observes the eye and the sense-field of form in this way. He is not attached to eye-consciousness, and attains freedom from desire and defilements.

Eye-consciousness is not the self, and the self does not have eye-consciousness. Contact, feeling, perception, and volition are also like this. Observing the eye and form is the fifth ground, not further opened in the thirteen.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£u knows the fruits of karma and observes the world of hungry ghosts.
With his wisdom of hearing, he observes the hungry ghosts that eat small children. Due to what karma are they born there?
With his wisdom of hearing, he knows:
These sentient beings use evil techniques to curse dragons, to remove hail, and to deceive the sick.
They use spells to control the yaká¹£as, to take people's wealth, or to kill sheep.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Such a person, when their body perishes and life ends, falls into the AvÄ«ci Hell and experiences immeasurable suffering. After leaving the hells, they are born among the Poluopucha hungry ghosts (Poluopucha means 'eating small children' in Wei).

There are also sentient beings who, due to the remaining karmic retribution of killing, are born among humans as these hungry ghosts, stealing and eating them. They may go to the places where women have just given birth and take their infants - whether crawling or just beginning to walk. Such hungry ghosts steal the small children and eat them in sequence.
If they find an opportunity, they can take their lives;
if there is no killing karma, they cannot harm them.
The verse says:
Bound by evil karma, one receives evil fruits; if one performs good karma, one receives pleasant rewards.
The rope of karma is long and strong, binding people; it binds all sentient beings, preventing them from escaping.
Unable to attain the city of peaceful nirvÄá¹‡a, one flows for a long time in the three existences, experiencing various sufferings.
Able to cut through this karma with the sword of wisdom, one will certainly attain liberation from all afflictions.
By severing the rope of karma and being unfettered, one will reach the place of tranquil quiescence beyond conditioned existence,
Just as a fish in a net is dragged by a person, so is the death of beings bound by craving.
Just as a person shoots a poisoned arrow at a wild deer, and the deer runs wildly back and forth in fear,
Once the poison takes effect, there is no escape; so it is with beings bound by craving.
It always follows beings without letting go; one should view craving as poison and stay far away from it,
Foolish ordinary beings are burned by craving, just as dry firewood is consumed by a great fire.
This initial defilement of craving is difficult to perceive, but its retribution is like fire that burns itself out,
If one wishes for constant happiness and peace of mind, one should abandon the bonds of craving and let go of all attachments.
Just as a fish that swallows a hook does not have long to live, so it is with a person bound by the bonds of craving,
Falling into the hungry ghost realm, tormented by hunger and thirst.ğŸ”½The various sufferings in the hungry ghost realm,
Fleeing here and there,ğŸ”½Those who experience suffering in the hells,
All due to the causes and conditions of the bonds of craving.ğŸ”½If there are poor, suffering, and sick people,
Seeking alms for their own sustenance,ğŸ”½All due to the causes and conditions of the bonds of craving,
They receive this suffering retribution as taught by the sages.

' In this way, fully contemplating all the causes and conditions and retributions of greed and jealousy, one attains aversion towards birth and death in the cycle of life and death, and abandons all desires.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and contemplate the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they contemplate the hungry ghosts who eat human essence and vitality. Due to what karma are they born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:
These sentient beings, in their past lives, used skillful words to deceive people, falsely claiming to be close friends:
'I will protect you.'
When that person hears this, they muster their courage and strength.

At that time, that person causes others to enter the enemy's ranks, and when their life is about to be lost, they abandon them and leave, ultimately not rescuing and protecting them. They want to take their wealth from the king. At that time, the deceived person drowns in the battle and dies.

Because of this unwholesome cause, when their body perishes and their life ends, they fall into the hungry ghosts that eat people's vital energy. They experience great hunger and thirst, burning their own bodies, and knives cut their body, skin, and flesh to pieces. Knives rain from the sky, and they run in all directions, having nowhere to escape.
If they see someone who acts badly and has no faith, who does not revere the Three Jewels, they can then enter their body and eat their vital energy to sustain their own life.
It is very difficult to find, and they are unable to get anything. Sometimes after ten years or twenty years they get a chance, but they are always suffering from hunger and thirst.

One creates evil karma and then experiences it oneself. Because the evil karma is not exhausted, one is not allowed to die. As long as the evil karma is not exhausted, lost, or decayed, one cannot escape;
only when the karma is exhausted can one escape.
After death, one is reborn among humans, always guarding the heavenly sacrifices, poor and destitute, without freedom, eating the leftovers of the sacrifices.
Due to the remaining karma, one depends on others for survival.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they see hungry ghosts called BrahmarÄká¹£asas. Due to what karma are they born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:
In a past life, these beings killed living beings for a great assembly, considering it rare;
they bought and sold food, buying cheap and selling expensive, greedy and jealous, and destructive.

Such beings, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into the realm of hungry ghosts, known as brahmin rÄká¹£asa hungry ghosts. They are burned by the fires of hunger and thirst, run about wildly, appearing to people as if they were going to kill them, and seek opportunities to harm people in empty alleys, crossroads, and street corners.
Many are born among them in brahmin sacrifices.
Some hide their bodies to kill people, some enter people's bodies to end people's lives.
Sorcerers say:
Ghosts and spirits possess people.
Having entered a person's body, they cause the person's mind to be disturbed, insane, and ignorant.
Such evil karma always creates various evils, and is burned by hunger and thirst, suffering greatly, dwelling in the realm of hungry ghosts.
Until the evil karma is exhausted, destroyed, and decayed, one cannot escape;
when the karma is exhausted and one's life ends, due to the causes and conditions of other karma, one is born among humans, always eating human flesh or drinking human blood.
Due to other karmic actions, they receive such retributions.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they observe the hungry ghosts who eat from fire stoves. Due to what karmic actions are they born in that place?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:
These sentient beings stay away from good friends, and greed and jealousy cover their minds, delighting in eating the food of the Saá¹…gha.
Such people, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into hell and experience immeasurable suffering.
After coming out of hell, they are born among the kumbhÄá¹‡á¸a hungry ghosts (kumbhÄá¹‡á¸a means fire stove in Wei).
After being born, hunger and thirst burn their bodies like a fire burning a forest, and they run around everywhere seeking food and drink.
Deceived by their own karmic actions, in heavenly temples they eat the remaining food that has been burned, mixed with fire.
Their minds always think of the remaining food from the fire stove. Hunger and thirst burn their bodies, and the two fires arise together, causing them to moan and wail.
All the evil karma they create will definitely ripen, and they will not be able to escape until their evil karma is exhausted.

When their karma is exhausted, they will escape and, due to the causes and conditions of their remaining karma, be born among humans, poor and sick, constantly burned by fire wherever they go, and burned by wild fires.
Due to the causes and conditions of their remaining karma, they will experience such retribution.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they contemplate:
Those who frequently practice jealousy and habitual pervasive karma, when their karma is completed, fall into the realm of hungry ghosts and are born in filthy alleys.
What karmic actions cause one to be born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they see:
These sentient beings, with minds covered by greed and jealousy, give filthy food to pure practitioners.
Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they are born among the filthy RÄjarasÄ« hungry ghosts (RÄjarasÄ« means alleys in Wei).
If it is daytime, people cannot see them;
if people walk at night, they see many of them.

If it is a place where many people gather, such as a city, town, or village, or if it is a place of filth and evil, such as a wilderness, military camp, or latrine, filled with maggots and foul-smelling impurities;
if people see them, they dislike looking at them, vomit, and leave.

But these hungry ghosts are born in such places, because in their past lives they gave impure food to the Saá¹…gha. For this cause and condition, they are born in impure places and experience great suffering.

Although they are in such places, they never get to eat. There are evil ghosts with sharp knives in their hands, flames shooting out from the blades, guarding them on the sides, always starving and thirsty.
Every half month, they get to eat once, but still cannot get full;
even if they get to eat until full, the ghosts guarding the feces forcefully beat them until they vomit.
Hungry and thirsty, burning their bodies, moaning and wailing, running around in confusion, worried and crying, they then spoke a verse, saying:
Because of the unwholesome causes and conditions of seeds, one obtains the evil fruits of sorrow and suffering,
The nature of cause and effect is similar, and due to unwholesome causes and conditions, one obtains the retribution of suffering.
Dragged by the hook of unwholesome karma, like a fish swallowing a hook and entering a bad path,
A fish that has swallowed a hook can still escape, but one dragged by unwholesome karma has no escape.
The great power of karma drags sentient beings, bound by the rope of unwholesome karma,
Leading them to the realm of hungry ghosts, where they experience the great suffering of hunger and thirst.
The suffering of hunger and thirst of hungry ghosts surpasses fire, swords, and poison,
Such hunger and thirst have great power, and immeasurable hunger and thirst torment sentient beings.
Not having a single moment of rest, day and night they are always separated from suffering,
Not even able to obtain a little happiness, they always experience various kinds of bitter suffering.
Because of the causes and conditions of creating suffering karma, they are born in evil realms and experience the retribution of suffering,
In this retribution it is difficult to escape, when will they be able to experience happiness?
All the springs seen are without water, all the ponds and lakes are dried up,
Fleeing everywhere in search of water and juice, going to all the rivers they do not see any.
Wherever I go in search of water, the mountains, forests, and wilderness are all without,
Wherever I arrive hoping for water to drink, seeking a little water I am unable to obtain it,
The fire of hunger and thirst burns my body, without refuge or rescue I experience great suffering.'
In this way the hungry ghosts are deceived by their own karma, moaning and wailing, until their evil karma is exhausted, and thus they are unable to escape.
When their retribution is exhausted and their lives end, due to their remaining karma, they are reborn among humans, receiving the bodies of various prostitutes and women;
if they obtain a male body, they are born in a family that removes excrement, wearing the clothes worn by women and practicing the ways of women.
This is due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts. Due to what karma are they born among the hungry ghosts that eat wind?
They know with their wisdom of hearing:

These sentient beings see various Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, the poor and sick come to beg for food, and promise to give them food, but when they come, they do not give at all, causing these Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and the poor and sick to be hungry and thirsty, like touching a cold wind.
Those who lie, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into the hungry ghosts that eat wind in the Bhimavará¹£a (Wei means 'wind-eating hungry ghosts').

Having already received a ghost body, the suffering of hunger and thirst is no different from that of the living hells. They run in all directions, with nothing to hope for, no one to rescue or protect them, with no reliance or support.

Deceived by their own minds, they see food and drink from afar, in the forest or in the dwelling place of monks. They rush there, exhausted and exhausted, hungry and thirsty as usual, opening their mouths to seek food, with wind entering their mouths as food and drink.
Because of the evil karmic conditions, they are not allowed to die.
The body is held by evil karma, and falsely sees the thought of food. It is like a thirsty deer seeing a mirage and calling it water, which is empty and nothing. Like a spinning fire wheel.
In previous lives, they falsely promised people but never gave them anything. For this retribution, they only see food with their eyes but cannot obtain it.
The verse says:
The sages say that cause and effect are similar. Good causes and good fruits are accomplished.
Good causes do not receive bad results, and bad causes will never receive good rewards.
Causes and conditions are mutually supportive, binding sentient beings, and the continuity of birth and death is like a chain.
Birth and death bind all sentient beings, cycling through the realms without being able to escape.
If one can sever all bonds, the firm chains of karma and afflictions,
That person will be able to reach the place of tranquility, forever severing all worries and afflictions.'

When that person experiences the suffering retribution of similar causes in this way, deceived by his own mind, he runs wildly, always eating wind and breath to sustain his life, until his evil karma is exhausted, destroyed, and decayed, and he is thus unable to escape.

When his karma is exhausted and his life ends, he is reborn among humans, poor and lowly, despised by others, always having his house, food, clothing, and belongings given to him by others, but no one gives him anything.
When hearing others promise, the mind is delighted with the hope of obtaining, but later not getting it, it turns to worry and distress, experiencing two kinds of suffering:
first, hunger and thirst;
second, worry and anxiety.
Experiencing great suffering and distress, due to other karma, one receives such retribution.
The verse says:
Thus sentient beings are perfumed by evil karma, experiencing various kinds of suffering and distress,
like the stench of being perfumed by excrement, such evil karma should be abandoned.
The perfume of good dharmas is most excellent, able to permanently part from the suffering of evil paths,
like the fragrant oil perfumed by champak flowers, although the flowers perish, the fragrant oil remains.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and contemplate the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they contemplate the hungry ghosts who eat burning charcoal. Due to what karma are they born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:

This being is the warden of the prison, with a mind covered by greed and jealousy, beating and binding beings, restricting their food and drink, causing them to starve and thirst, eating mud and soil to sustain their lives.
This prison warden, due to these causes and conditions, when his body perishes and his life ends, falls into the hungry ghost realm of fire-eaters.
Always going to the charnel ground, eating the fire that burns corpses, still it is not enough.

Such evil karma, at the time of its cause, is delightful, but upon receiving its retribution, it is extremely distressing and not pleasing to the mind. Impure and detestable, the power of the poison of desire and the combination of causes and conditions result in the body of a hungry ghost that eats fire.
If it obtains fire to eat, it slightly alleviates the distress of hunger, just as a person extinguishes worldly fire with water.
When the bhiká¹£u contemplates in this way, he deeply gives rise to disgust towards the desires of the world, not delighting in being together with them, and thinks like this:
'Foolish ordinary beings are controlled by desire and lack self-mastery.'
Eating fire to relieve hunger cannot be compared to this. One receives the body of a hungry ghost until one's evil karma is exhausted and destroyed, and therefore one cannot escape.

When the karma is exhausted and one's life ends, one is born among humans, always born in borderlands of famine and scarcity, eating coarse and evil food without any delicious flavors, not knowing the taste of salt.
Due to the remaining karma, one receives such retribution.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the world of hungry ghosts.
With their wisdom of hearing, they contemplate the hungry ghosts who eat poison. Due to what karma are they born there?
With their wisdom of hearing, they know:
These sentient beings, with greed and jealousy covering their minds, use poisoned food to kill people and take their wealth.
Such evil people, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into the AvÄ«ci Hell and experience all kinds of suffering.

After leaving the hells, they are reborn among the hungry ghosts who eat poison, living in the caves of Mount Mandara, or in the deep mountains of PÄriyÄtra, or in the extremely cold places of Mount HimÄlaya, or on Mount Malaya, in extremely dangerous and poisonous places, with no water or many poisonous drugs, freezing in the cold and poisonous in the heat, extremely terrifying, with clumps of rocks and steep cliffs inhabited by lions and tigers, and they are born there.
The suffering of the cold is extremely tormenting, a hundred times worse than that of humans. In the summer heat, it is a hundred times more tormenting than that of humans.
In the height of summer, for five days the sky rains fire, burning their bodies;
In the extreme winter cold, for five days the sky rains knives.
Due to their evil karma, the sky rains fire and rain swords. Living in dangerous places, they are burned by the fires of hunger and thirst. They cry out in grief and eat poisonous pills themselves.
